The "Airport Improvement Program Temporary Extension Act of 1994" authorizes $15,413,157,000 for fiscal years before October 1, 1994. It also adjusts the obligational authority to June 30, 1994. SEC. 102 amends the Airport and Airway Improvement Act of 1982 by adjusting the amount to be obligated to less than $1,900,000,000. SEC. 103 increases the minimum amount for primary airports from $400,000 to $500,000. SEC. 104 establishes a discretionary fund. Minimum Amount To Be Credited under the Airport and Airway Improvement Act of 1982 is amended to ensure that not less than $325,000,000 is credited to the discretionary fund annually. The Airport and Airway Improvement Act of 1982 is amended to ensure that a total amount of $325,000,000 is subject to reduction annually, divided into various subsections for equal percentage reduction. The Airport and Airway Improvement Act of 1982 is amended to reduce a total amount of $325,000,000 annually by equal percentage reductions, with the amendment taking effect on July 1, 1994. SEC. 105. USE OF APPORTIONED AND DISCRETIONARY FUNDS. Amendments made to reduce percentages in various paragraphs. SEC. 106. REIMBURSEMENT FOR PAST EXPENDITURES. Section 513(a)(2) of the Airport and Airway Improvement Act of 1982 is amended to include provisions for incurred expenses during fiscal year 1994 with specific conditions for eligibility and federal share payment. The Federal share for expenses incurred in fiscal year 1994 is only paid with apportioned sums under specific sections. SEC. 107. TERMINAL DEVELOPMENT. Section 513(b)(2) of the Airport and Airway Improvement Act of 1982 is amended to allow the Secretary to approve the use of funds for reliever airports and primary airports with low enplanements. Additionally, sums distributed under sections 507(c) and 507(d) can be used by primary airports with low enplanements. The Secretary can approve funds for reliever airports and primary airports with low enplanements, allowing them to use sums distributed under sections 507(c) and 507(d) for project costs. SEC. 108 amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding expenditures from the Airport and Airway Trust Fund. SEC. 109 addresses upward adjustments. SEC. 109 of the Airport and Airway Improvement Act of 1982 is amended to allow for upward adjustments in funds recovered by the United States from grants. The amendment is retroactively effective from October 1, 1993. The Airport and Airway Improvement Act of 1982 is amended to allow air carriers to file complaints with the Secretary regarding unreasonable fees imposed by airport owners. The Secretary must provide the airport operator an opportunity to respond before issuing an order. Frivolous complaints may be refused by the Secretary. The Secretary must issue an order within 7 days of a complaint being filed, prohibiting the airport owner from collecting an increased fee unless deemed reasonable. The order expires on June 30, 1994, and does not apply if informal mediation assistance was requested. The airport operator and affected air carrier can submit comments on the complaint within a specified period. Based on comments and material provided, the Secretary may take action on the complaint, including termination or modification of any order issued. This section does not apply to fees under a binding agreement with air carriers using airport facilities and does not affect existing agreements between carriers and airport owners. SEC. 202 of the title defines "fee" as any charge for airport facility use and "Secretary" as the Secretary of Transportation. The Secretary of Transportation will conduct a study on reforms to improve the air traffic control system of the Federal Aviation Administration, aiming to enhance services, reduce costs, and maintain safety and accessibility. The study will evaluate reforms to streamline procurement, attract and retain staff, simplify personnel processes, ensure funding stability, leadership continuity, and reduce management oversight. The study conducted by the Secretary of Transportation will evaluate possible reforms to improve the air traffic control system, including streamlining procurement, personnel processes, and reducing management oversight. The study will also assess existing laws and regulations that may be hindering the system's operation or modernization. The results of the study will be compiled in a report to be completed within 180 days of the enactment of the Act. The Secretary of Transportation will transmit the report to Congress upon completion, within 180 days of the Act's enactment or the submission of proposed legislation for a separate air traffic control entity. TITLE IV_MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS

SEC. 401. GRANDFATHER PROVISION FOR FAA DEMONSTRATION PROJECT. The Federal Aviation Administration will continue to pay quarterly retention allowance payments to certain employees despite the termination of the demonstration project. The amount of the payment will be based on the last payment received before June 17, 1994, with adjustments for any increase in the employee's annual rate of basic pay. The allowance payment is based on the employee's annual rate of basic pay increase after June 17, 1994, including various types of pay increases under different sections of title 5, United States Code. The allowance payment is calculated based on the employee's annual rate of basic pay increase after June 17, 1994, including different types of pay increases under various sections of title 5, United States Code. For employees on leave without pay or similar status before June 17, 1994, the last quarterly retention allowance payment under the personnel demonstration project will be considered for computation purposes. The quarterly retention allowance payment for employees is based on their pay status and entitlement under the demonstration project. The entitlement ceases when the allowance is reduced to zero or when the employee separates or moves to a position not eligible for the allowance before June 17, 1994. The Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration may make special payments for costs incurred between June 18, 1994, and September 30, 1994. The Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration will conduct a study on recruitment and retention incentives for air traffic controllers at hard-to-staff facilities. The study will evaluate special incentives, financial or non-financial, to address staffing levels. A report on the study's results is due to the Senate and House committees within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration will conduct a study on recruitment and retention incentives for air traffic controllers at hard-to-staff facilities. A report on the study's results, planned administrative actions, and any recommended legislation is required within 180 days of the Act's enactment.
